channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: If All Else Fails, 3D Models and Robots Might Rebuild Sites
item.description: Cultural organizations have been working to create precise 3D digital models of the threatened heritage monuments in Palmyra, Syria, in case the originals are damaged beyond repair.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN FARRELL
item.media:credit: Institute for Digital Archaeology and Tor Art
item.media:description: A small-scale reproduction of a Roman triumphal arch in Palmyra being carved from a 3D computer model in Carrara, Italy, this month. The original arch in Palmyra was destroyed by ISIS.

item.title: Editorial: Another Bombing, This Time in Pakistan
item.description: The Pakistani government has long cynically used Taliban groups as proxy fighters.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Mourning for the victims of the suicide bombing in Lahore, Pakistan.

item.title: Editorial: Mr. Trump’s Dangerous Babble on Foreign Policy
item.description: Donald Trump offers up disturbing, incoherent views on nuclear weapons and other national security issues.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Israel Changes Tack After Standoff With Brazil Over Dani Dayan
item.description: Plans to name the former settler leader as envoy to the South American nation were dropped after Brasília refused to approve the appointment.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The former settler leader Dani Dayan, who has been appointed consul general in New York, at a conference in Jerusalem on Monday on fighting a boycott against Israeli goods.

item.title: Scenes From Palmyra Indicate ISIS Slowed Assault on Treasures
item.description: A day after Syrian troops recaptured the city, television footage showed “severe” damage to ancient sculptures. But there was hope that many works could be reconstructed.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Syria’s antiquities director, Maamoun Abdulkarim, said 80 percent of the Unesco World Heritage site encompassing the ancient ruins of Palmyra was intact.

item.title: World Briefing: Cameroon: Doubts That Bomber is Kidnapped Student
item.description: The authorities in Cameroon expressed doubt that a would-be suicide bomber she was one of the Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram in 2014.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: U.N. Decision Expands Maritime Territory
item.description: The move expanded Argentina’s territory in the South Atlantic Ocean by 35 percent to include the disputed Falkland Islands and beyond.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: President Won’t Fund Leftist TV Network
item.description: Argentina’s president, Mauricio Macri, will cut its funding of a regional television network started by the Venezuelan government in 2005.
item.dc:creator: FREDERICK BERNAS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: More Peacekeepers Accused
item.description: The United Nations is investigating two new suspected cases of sexual abuse committed by peacekeepers in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Keen Pain in Pakistan Over Lives ‘Shattered Into Pieces’
item.description: Grief enveloped Pakistan after an instant of calculated cruelty thrust families onto a long roll call of bombing victims. “Within minutes, I lost my wife,” a man said. “I couldn’t save her.”
item.dc:creator: DANIYAL HASSAN, NAILA INAYAT and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: ‘Lula,’ Ex-President of Brazil, Lashes Out at Judge Overseeing Corruption Inquiry
item.description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva said the judge, Sergio Moro, was trying to ruin him by releasing intercepts of his telephone conversations.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil, shown Monday, accused the judge looking into the country’s graft scandal of trying to ruin him.

item.title: Fidel Castro Criticizes Barack Obama’s Efforts to Change Cuba
item.description: “We do not need the empire to give us anything,” the former president of Cuba wrote in Granma, the official Communist Party newspaper.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Man Arrested as ‘Third Bomber’ in Brussels Attack Is Freed; Hunt Is Renewed
item.description: The police, appealing to the public for help, said the real assailant remained at large.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolling in Brussels on Sunday.

item.title: Vietnam’s Battle With Tuberculosis
item.description: A country’s stunning progress against tuberculosis may be threatened by reduced support for a health care system stretched thin.
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:credit: Justin Mott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nguyen Quang Thieu, 53, waiting to have his lung X-Ray scan examined by Dr. Hoang Thi Phuong, head of the Respiratory Tuberculosis Department at the National Lung Hospital in Hanoi.

item.title: Saudis Announce Prisoner Swap With Houthis in Yemen Conflict
item.description: It was only the second publicly announced prisoner swap since the Saudis’ intervention a year ago, and by far the biggest, ahead of a planned April 10 cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Houthi rebels at a tribal gathering showing support for the Houthi movement in Sana, Yemen, last year. Saudi Arabia released 109 Yemenis in return for nine Saudis in a prisoner swap with the Houthi rebels announced Monday.

item.title: Raghavendran Ganesan, Software Engineer From India, Dies in Brussels Attack
item.description: Mr. Ganesan’s family appealed to Indian officials and others via social media in a frantic search for their lost relative.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS
item.media:description: Raghavendran Ganesan, in a photograph taken from social media.

item.title: Lauriane Visart, 27, Belgian Lawyer, Dies in Brussels Attacks
item.description: Many Belgians got to know Ms. Visart, who was killed in a suicide attack at the Maelbeek subway station, after her father gave a moving interview.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Lauriane Visart in a photograph taken from social media.

item.title: Bangladesh Editor Faces 79 Court Cases After an Unusual Confession
item.description: After admitting it was wrong to have years ago published allegations against the prime minister, Mahfuz Anam could be sentenced to 175 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR
item.media:description: Mahfuz Anam, center, the editor of The Daily Star, Bangladesh’s most popular English-language newspaper, outside a court in Rangpur District this month.

item.title: In 2 Minutes, Bangladesh Rejects 28-Year-Old Challenge to Islam’s Role
item.description: The High Court dismissed a petition, filed in 1988, that aimed to remove the designation of Islam as the state religion and struck a nerve among Bangladeshis.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Leaders of an Islamic group gave gestures of victory in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Monday after the country’s top court dismissed a petition that aimed to remove the designation of Islam as the state religion.

item.title: Victims of the Brussels Attacks
item.description: Thirty-five victims from at least eight countries were killed in the attacks. Here are profiles of some of the victims, updated as more names are confirmed.
